ESTIMATES OF EXPENDITURE FOR THE FINANCIAL YEAR
1ST APRIL, 1994 TO 31ST MARCH, 1995
(Paper Cmd. 2 of 1994)


    Order read for consideration in Committee of Supply [1st Allotted Day].

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]



     The Chairman: Estimates of Expenditure for the financial year 1st April 1994 to 31st March 1995, contained in Paper Cmd. 2 of 1994. I shall take the totals for each head of expenditure in the Main and Development Estimates appearing in the last columns of the Main and Development Outlays for FY 94 on pages 43 and 44 respectively of the Command Paper.

    Besides the "guillotine" times for heads of expenditure, which I have fixed under Standing Order 89(7)(a), I have also allotted the time for the discussion of each amendment in the Estimates. I shall announce these times as we go along.

    In addition to the extension of the sitting time of the Committee by half an hour on each of the seven allotted days, I have also increased the number of allotted days by one day to eight days. However, even with these increases of time, we will, I expect, be hard pressed for time.

    Members will therefore not be allotted the time they have requested for discussing their amendments. I shall

Column: 669

confine speeches to certain time limits wherever it is necessary to do so. While I shall try to keep the proceedings moving at a brisk pace, I would ask Members on both sides of the House to keep their speeches short and sweet so that we can complete our business expeditiously.

    I shall deal first with the heads of expenditure in respect of which amendments stand on the Order Paper Supplement.

    Head V -

     Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head V of the Development Estimates be reduced by $10 in respect of Code VA 5100.

    (In Mandarin): Sir, the Development Estimates have increased tremendously under the Prime Minister's Office. There is a seven-fold increase, about $9.14 million for Istana and $3.11 million for the renovation of Command House, and $2.6 million for the completion of some projects. Apart from MND spending about $10 million for the renovation of the Istana Park outside the Istana entrance, we are now spending such a lot of money to renovate Istana. Why is it necessary to carry out the massive renovations? I would ask the Prime Minister to justify this renovation.

    Secondly, the renovation of Command House. According to Lianhe Zaobao, this will become the official residence of the Elected President. I do not understand. Istana is meant for the President. Why does the Government want to spend so much money to renovate Istana and, at the same time, spend another big sum of money to renovate Command House for the Elected President? Is it necessary?

    Thirdly, some completed projects needed $2.6 million. What sort of projects were involved and when were these projects completed?

     The Acting Minister for National Development (Mr Lim Hng Kiang): Sir, first, let me clarify the $10 million that has been spent for the Istana Park is the park outside the Istana. It is not in Istana.

Column: 670

We name it Istana Park, but it is intended for the use of the Singaporean public. It is a piece of land outside the Istana, along Orchard Road. So he should not ascribe the $10 million to renovation within the Istana.

    The second point is: why is there a need to refurbish Istana? The Istana buildings are very old. The main building was built in 1869, that is about 125 years ago. Minor renovations have been done over the years but the building requires upgrading to meet present-day needs. Space and facilities for the staff and for holding state functions are very limited. The Government has therefore decided to have a major renovation to the Istana to upgrade and modernise the mechanical and electrical services and facilities as well as to build an extension block to provide the additional space.

    Let me elaborate the reasons why we have to refurbish the Istana. First, there is an acute shortage of functional space in Istana. Because of this constraint, the Government has to limit the number of guests to be invited to state functions, for example, state banquets for visiting heads of state or other ceremonial functions. Second, the Banquet Room and the State Room have to double up for use as wet weather programme for garden functions. Each time when there is a garden reception, as a precaution for wet weather, all the tables and chairs in the Banquet Room and State Room have to be removed and stacked away along the corridors and tarpaulins rolled on to the floors to protect the carpets. This is very labour intensive. It will also incur maintenance cost. It is also very unsightly for guests to see all the tables and chairs stacked along the corridors. Therefore, in the proposed renovation, a new multi-purpose hall will be created to serve the purpose of wet weather programme. Proper storerooms are also built to store the furniture.

    Third, there is also a shortage of space for the staff working in the Istana. There are no common rooms for the staff to rest when they are required to stay back in the evening to organise official functions and attend to the guests. The staff have to rest along the corridors.

Column: 671



    Finally, most of the M&E equipment in the Istana are 15-20 years old, beyond their normal lifespan. It costs us a large amount to maintain them and they are in need of replacement. For these reasons, therefore, the Government decided to refurbish the Istana.

    As for the Command House, the Command House was also built a long time ago. It was built in 1938. It was used as the official residence of the Speaker of Parliament from 1972 to 1989. The current Speaker had decided not to live in the Command House. The House was therefore put up for rent. We managed to find two short-term tenants. The House has been vacant since March last year because there were no suitable tenants to be found. The existing House is not properly furnished and its provisions are very basic. The Government has therefore decided to renovate the building and upgrade the mechanical and electrical systems. After renovation, the Command House will be used as the official residence of the Elected President.

    So the refurbishment of the Istana is primarily to serve state functions. The refurbishment of the Command House will serve as the official residence of the Elected President.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, the Minister mentioned about staff. Approximately, how many staff are working in the Istana? As for the renovation of Command House, I understand that previously the President had been living in the Istana. Since we are going to renovate Istana, why can we not have an extension for the President to live there? Why is there a need to further renovate Command House? What would happen if, say, the next Elected President decides not to live there, just like the Speaker of the House? What are you going to do then?

    The other question which the Minister has not answered is the $2.6 million of completed projects. What are the projects?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: I do not have the specific number of staff that the President has. The main part of the refurbishment of the Istana is in the refurbishment of the

Column: 672

old buildings. Many of our old buildings, City Hall, etc., have to be refurbished after 100 years. The buildings are in a very bad state. So it is mainly to refurbish the buildings. Part of the other reason is of course to create office space and rooms for the staff. I do not have the exact numbers but I will find it out and pass it to the Member.

    The second point is: why can the Elected President not stay in the Istana? As he well knows, the main building of the Istana and the Annexe are used as offices for the Elected President, the Prime Minister and the Senior Minister, as well as rooms for state functions. The previous President lived in another small building on the Istana grounds, called the Istana Lodge. During this refurbishment, the Istana Lodge will be used as a temporary office for the President and his staff. This allows us to make use of the building while we are refurbishing the main building. Otherwise, we have to find temporary offices for the Elected President.

    On the question of $2.6 million, I am not sure where the Member gets the figure. Maybe he could enlighten me.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: It is in the Budget book. It was for completed projects.

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Is it related to Istana and Command House?

     The Chairman: Order. It is ``guillotine'' time. Mr Low, do you want to withdraw your amendment?

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, I beg to withdraw my amendment.

Column: 673



    Sir, in the past several years, the security situation in the world, and in particular in this region, has undergone dramatic changes. While the threat of nuclear wars has abated somewhat, the same cannot be said of the conventional conflicts which have affected many countries in Europe and Africa. A more disturbing trend is that many of these conflicts arose as a result of internal problems relating to ethnic and cultural backgrounds of the people rather than from external sources. We are more blessed in nature where rapid economic development in most countries in the Pacific Rim has brought about prosperity and improved well-being to the people. There is less opportunity for conflicts as everyone is preoccupied with improving the standard of living. To a large extent, many people would hold the view that wars are no longer imminent and we will reduce the emphasis we have placed so far on defence.

    In Singapore, we have always taken the position that it is far better to be prepared than to be caught unaware no matter how remote the possibility of conflicts that may arise, given the multi-racial and cultural nature of our society. We have for some years now subscribed to the concept of Total Defence encompassing Military, Civil, Economic, Social and Psychological Defence. Each of these aspects is relevant to the particular structure of our society. Each of these policies needs to be reviewed and varied where necessary so that they may remain relevant to our security needs.

    It would be useful for the Minister to brief the House on the changes that have been brought about in the past year to maintain our military capability. Since the five areas of Total Defence are closely linked, the Minister may also wish to enlighten the House on the progress that has been made to the implementation of the Total Defence policy. I know that the Minister will be tempted to ask the other Ministers to answer the other four polices, but I submit that since the Minister for Defence is in overall charge

Column: 674

of Total Defence, the Minister may find it more convenient to do on behalf of his colleagues.

     The Chairman: Mr Chiam is not here. Dr Lau Teik Soon.

     Dr Lau Teik Soon (Thomson GRC): Sir, defence analysts have noted a worrying trend with regard to defence expenditures of states in the Asia-Pacific region. With increased growth rates of many states in the region, for example, in the case of China, double digit growth over the last few years, and some of the ASEAN states experiencing growth rates of over 6%, more money is available for the defence establishments in these countries. At the same time, there are a number of countries offering very sophisticated weapons at bargain prices. It seems that there is a rush to buy sophisticated weapons on the part of many states, whether it be F16s, SU29, radar installations or any other weapons.

    The reasons for the increased expenditures are many. They include the modernisation programmes of defence forces, the need to enhance defence capability and to contribute to regional security. However, there is the view that defence build-up may lead in fact to an arms race among the states in the region. This is worrying because there are many potential conflict issues in the Asia-Pacific relating to territorial disputes, competition over resources and age-old problems, for example, in the Korean Peninsula.

    To prevent misunderstanding, Sir, it is important therefore for states to promote defence cooperation among themselves, especially among states within the sub-region. Various cooperative measures can be adopted, for example, exchange of visits, joint exercises, exchange of information, bilateral arrangements and even multi-lateral defence arrangements.

    Sir, I would like to ask the Minister to inform the House what forms of defence cooperation have been implemented between Singapore and other states in the region, especially our ASEAN neighbours.

     Dr Ho Tat Kin (Toa Payoh GRC): Sir, over the years, increasing competing demands

Column: 675

for land use as industrial, residential and national development projects have reduced the land available for military training. Many areas previously used by the SAF are no longer available. Tampines is now developed into a residential area. JTC has taken back Woodlands and Loyang for industrial development. Parts of Lim Chu Kang and Yio Chu Kang are now used for high-tech farming. Only about 15% of the total land area is available for SAF training purposes. Yet providing realistic training is the cornerstone of a credible and modern fighting army.

    Sir, space constraint is not limited to land but also air space. Local air space available for air force flight training is minimal. Singapore's air space is already very small and yet a significant proportion of the air space is being crowded by complex and block systems of flight paths and air corridors serving civilian airline flights. This is expected to increase in the coming years. The air space for training can therefore be expected to be reduced even further. At the same time, access to certain hazardous zones such as flying over army live firing areas must continue to be restricted for safety reasons.

    Sir, traditionally in the 60s and 70s, Singapore had limited access to training space over peninsular Malaya. In 1983, Singapore and Malaya had an official agreement defining boundaries of what is known as the low flying area. But I understand that in February 1991, Malaysia has drastically reduced this by 85%. Our air force could of course conduct their training over the South China Sea, but this space is also used by other air forces for training. I understand that to fly to the training area, two-thirds of the flying time is used. In spite of the land and air space constraint, the SAF must train hard to maintain operational readiness.

    Sir, I would like to ask the Minister what alternatives have been provided to the SAF for training and how effective are these alternatives.

     The Second Minister for Defence (Dr Lee Boon Yang): Sir, I shall reply to the Chairman of the GPC for Defence and Foreign Affairs.

Column: 676



    Sir, in 1984, Mindef introduced the concept of Total Defence as Singapore's strategy for security. Total Defence comprises five aspects, as the Chairman of the GPC has mentioned, namely, Psychological Defence, Social Defence, Economic Defence, Civil Defence and Military Defence. Let me highlight the key principles of each of these elements.

    Sir, Psychological Defence is the foremost aspect of Total Defence. Psychological Defence is about the collective will to stand up for our right, to protect what is ours, and to prosper and progress in our own way as a nation.

    Social Defence is about our people living and working together in harmony. Social Defence strengthens Singapore's community spirit and ensures that the social cohesion we now enjoy will never disintegrate.

    Economic Defence is Government, business and industry, organising themselves in a manner such that our economy will never collapse when faced with adversity. If we slip behind economically, we also slip behind militarily. Economic Defence will ensure that we remain nimble, resilient and robust, able to deal with all forms of threats without allowing our economy to come to a standstill.

    Civil Defence is preparing and educating our people to respond to emergency situation and to ensure that life goes on as normally as possible. Civil Defence readiness means having adequate supplies of food, water, fuel, medicine, blood and so on. And the population, so well prepared, that they will not panic when disaster strikes.

    Military Defence is the ability to have credible defence strategy against threats to Singapore's sovereignty and territorial integrity. Military Defence is bolstered with a strong defence technological capability and an efficient defence industry.

    Sir, the Ministries of Community Development, Trade and Industry, Home Affairs, Information and the Arts and Mindef are responsible for the various aspects of Total Defence. A Total Defence

Column: 677

working committee chaired by the Head of Civil Service was formed in July 1985 to oversee the efforts of the various Ministries. This committee's main role is to mould attitudes towards Total Defence so that it becomes a conscious element in policy formulation by the Ministries and their statutory boards.

    Over the years, Mindef has worked with the other Total Defence Ministries to bring home to Singaporeans the importance of Total Defence. This has been carried out through various activities, campaigns and national education programmes run by the respective Ministries. Exercises have also been held, such as the Food and Fuel and Civil Defence Shelter exercises. Other preparatory measures have also been implemented such as the use of computers to monitor stocks of essential food items and construction of air-raid shelters.

    On Mindef's part, we have organised mass information campaigns and national education programmes to highlight the importance of Total Defence to Singaporeans. Last year, we launched a programme for national awareness for trainee teachers together with the Institute of Education. Teachers play a vital role in emphasising the importance of defence to young Singaporeans. The experience and exposure in this programme would generate confidence in the SAF among the teachers and enable them to convey the essential values and concept to our students.

    After the Total Defence plans were formalised in 1984, Mindef carried out an extensive public information campaign on the Total Defence concept. To regenerate awareness of Total Defence as Singapore's strategy for security, in July this year Mindef will once again launch a mass information campaign to educate younger Singaporeans who have not been exposed to this concept or are not totally familiar with Singapore's approach to security. Mindef together with the other Total Defence Ministries will continue with efforts to generate and give greater awareness of the Total Defence

Column: 678

programme so that every Singaporean understands his or her role in the defence of Singapore.

     The Minister for Defence (Dr Yeo Ning Hong): Sir, I will be responding to Prof. Lau and Dr Ho's points on defence cooperation and limitation of space for training.
2.00 pm

    Sir, Singapore's defence policy is based on a two-pronged approach of diplomacy and deterrence. We have built up a strong deterrence capability to deter threats to Singapore from surfacing. But deterrence alone is not enough. As a small nation, it is vital for Singapore to have good defence relations with as many countries as possible, especially with our neighbours in ASEAN. Hence, Mindef has an active policy of fostering good relations, building open and frank communications, enhancing common interests among our neighbours and other countries. Such relations will serve us in good stead and minimise the prospect of tension and instability in the future. Our efforts to establish close defence ties and strengthen relations with our neighbours and other armed forces have been successful. I will give a brief account of some of them.

    Mindef gives priority to maintaining close defence relations with our ASEAN partners. The SAF enjoys warm and cordial ties with the armed forces of the other ASEAN countries. These ties have been built up over the years and bilateral relations have been institutionalised. We hold regular bilateral exercises and annual bilateral games and facilitate regular exchange of visits. Our officers also attend each other's military academies and training institutions. The SAF now conducts regular bilateral exercises with all other ASEAN countries, the most recent country being the Philippines. We place great emphasis on such bilateral military exercises which have over the years grown both in scope and sophistication.

    The Air Forces and Navies of the ASEAN countries also hold regular bilateral exercises. Our Air Force, for

Column: 679

example, exercises annually with the Indonesian Air Force and the Royal Thai Air Force, while our Navy has regular bilateral exercises with the Navies of Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand and Brunei.

    Our close ties with our ASEAN friends are also manifested in the training opportunities that they have granted to the SAF. Indonesia, Thailand and Brunei allow Singapore Armed Forces to carry out unilateral exercises in their countries.

    The Air Combat Manoeuvring Range in Sumatra which we develop jointly together with the Indonesian Air Force will be commissioned later this month. Last year, Thailand renewed the training arrangement for the SAF and the RSAF to train in Thailand itself.

    Sir, I now move on to the relations with the Five Power Defence Arrangement (FPDA) countries. The Five Power Defence Arrangement countries, namely, Malaysia, Australia, New Zealand, the United Kingdom and Singapore form a key institution contributing to the security of the region. The FPDA has served us well over the past two decades. Its value as a political and psychological deterrent has not diminished. This arrangement remains relevant to the region. Cooperation between the FPDA partners is excellent. The regular air defence and naval exercises have been broadened and interaction between FPDA defence officials institutionalised. This year, Singapore will be hosting the second meeting of the FPDA Defence Ministers and the Chiefs of Defence Forces will also be meeting in Malaysia later on in the year.

    Sir, the House is aware of our increasing defence ties with Australia. Last year, we signed the MOU to shift the RSAF Flying Training School to Pearce in Western Australia. The School has already started operations and it is progressing well. The permanent premises of the School are being built and should be completed this year, with the laying of the foundation stone of the building scheduled for later this month. Last year, we signed a defence cooperation and technology agreement with Australia to facilitate collaboration in

Column: 680

defence research and technology. And in December, we signed another MOU allowing our armoured troops to exercise in Australian territory this year. We also conduct regular joint exercises with the Australian Defence Forces and these exercises have proved to be extremely valuable to the Singapore Armed Forces.

    Sir, our defence ties with the United States are also excellent. We see the United States as a special friend and we regard continued US engagement in the region as important for regional stability. Singapore is not alone in supporting continued US presence. Over the past two years, many other countries in the region have also expressed in one form or another their view that the presence of US forces in the region is still vital and necessary to the continuous stability and security of the region.

    The SAF has regular exercises with US forces, in particular with the US forces under the US-Pacific Command. These exercises are carried out in Singapore, in Hawaii, in continental US, and in Alaska. Our three services have benefitted immensely from our interactions with the US forces. Mindef will continue with its active defence diplomacy to strengthen existing relations and forge new relations.

    Sir, Dr Ho has touched upon the scarcity of training space in Singapore. This is indeed a serious problem for the SAF and a very severe constraint. Over the years, the availability of training areas in Singapore has shrunk. The total land area available for training is now less than half the land available to the SAF in 1967. As Singapore develops, we can expect further encroachment on the training areas.

    Sir, we also face constraints in the air. When our Air Force jets take off, in less than a minute they are already out of Singapore airspace. That gives Members an idea of how small, how limited the airspace of Singapore is. But we cannot allow the lack of training area or the shortage of airspace to impede the training of the Singapore Armed Forces. We need to conduct regular and realistic training in order to hone the SAF into an

Column: 681

effective and efficient fighting force, a force that is capable of fulfilling its task and mission of safeguarding the sovereignty of Singapore.

    So, wherever possible, we have applied technology to help us resolve and overcome the problems related to shortage of training space and training area. Hence, the SAF has made extensive use of simulators. After training on the simulators, when our troops go out for actual exercises, they are able to maximise, to make the best use of, the very limited space that is available to us. In this way, every exercise in the training area is optimised to give the best possible training to our Armed Forces.

    Sir, let me assure Members that the drug enforcement and control problem will always remain the priority area in my Ministry's agenda. As Dr Arthur Beng rightly pointed out, the problem cannot be completely eradicated. We must relentlessly ensure that the situation is kept in check as much as possible.

    The drug situation in Singapore, as in any country, depends on several factors, for example, the supply of drugs from external sources, the changing patterns of drug consumption, and our enforcement and rehabilitation programmes which must continue with vigour.

    Over the last six years or so, relentless efforts have been put into enforcement against drug traffickers and addicts. Much emphasis was also put on rehabilitating the addicts. There were many innovative programmes being tried out such as the exit counselling programme, the use of electronic monitoring system and drug rehabilitation programme tailored to suit the various categories of drug abuses.

    Recently, our drug rehabilitation centres (DRCs) have seen an increase in the number of drug addicts. In 1993, for example, 4,740 addicts were admitted into the DRC as compared with, say, 3,823 in 1991. That shows an increase of 24%. The number of hardcore addicts, and by "hardcore" I mean those who are third timers and above, amongst them has also increased due to relapse. The number of hardcore addicts has increased from 48% in 1991 to 51% in 1993. The relapse rate now stands at 70%, which means that 70% of these drug addicts go back to taking drugs within two years after their release from the DRC. And we also keep the repeater drug addicts longer in the DRC. This has therefore contributed to the increase in the DRC population which is now about 8,130 as at the end of 1993. This increase indicates that we need to fine-tune and make adjustments to the current two-pronged strategy of curbing supply and demand.

    On the supply side, I have asked the CNB to step up its enforcement action against all drug traffickers, whether they are big, small or ant traffickers. For those who cannot be prosecuted in court because their witnesses or their accomplices are not willing to go to court and give evidence, then we will detain them under the Criminal Law (Temporary Provisions) Act. As at the end of December last year, we have 427 persons detained under the Criminal Law (Temporary Provisions) Act for drug trafficking.

The number of such real recalcitrant and hardcore addicts will only continue to grow if they keep on relapsing. So we must adopt a tougher approach towards such drug addicts. We will continue to detain them in the DRC for progressively longer periods and to add to the deterrent effect, my Ministry is also considering incorporating some of the features of prison life in the DRC regime. For example, we will lock them up for a longer period initially and we will introduce tougher physical drills and exercises. We will also cut down drastically on the privileges and the opportunities for recreational activities for these addicts.

    I am also considering whether for the truly hardcore addicts (fifth timers and above) that Dr Arthur Beng talked about, they should not be prosecuted in court and let the court decide to send them to jail, instead of the CNB sending them to the DRC. Compared with the prison, of course, the DRCs are more like camps and addicts sleep in dormitories, and drug addicts feel a sense of community because they are meeting their own kind when they are together. Like Dr Beng said, there is a sense of home-coming whenever they get back to the DRC. I think this situation is not on, whereas in jail, and "jail" literally means behind bars, I think these real hardcore addicts should have a taste of it.

In fact, under the Misuse of Drugs Act, anyone who is found guilty of drug-taking or smoking, self-administering, consuming controlled drugs is liable to be punished by up to 10 years of imprisonment or a fine of up to $20,000, or both. The minimum sentence for a second or subsequent offence where a person is sentenced by the court is three years' imprisonment. In the past, very few addicts were prosecuted because we have always treated them as patients and we try not to leave them with a conviction record. But if they choose to relapse repeatedly, then I do not see why they should not be sent to court and let the court send them to jail. If that is still insufficient deterrence, then we can consider introducing caning for such hardcore addicts, in addition to imprisonment.

Our records show that most of these hardcore addicts already have criminal records. Therefore, the argument of helping them to keep a clean record is not really valid. Our data show that for the more hardcore addicts, the more hardcore an addict becomes, the more likely he is to have a criminal record. For example, while 55% of the

compares and contrasts indeed to the 18 fatalities out of the 479 accidents over the same period where rear seat belts were not used. So the fact proves quite conclusively that if you put on your seat belt, and you are a rear seat passenger and there is an accident that involves injury, the chances are that you would not die from it. And I would not rule out the possibility of legislating this requirement in future. In fact, it is through all these measures that our traffic accident and fatality rate per hundred thousand population is comparable to, and in some cases better than, that of many other countries.
